Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Design Automation Infrastructure for DNA Assembly in Synthetic Biology

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual Merit
Synthetic biology attempts to design novel biological systems to address a number of challenges in bioenergy, biotherapeutics, and bioremediation. Synthetic biology computational tools must be closely coupled to experimental needs to transform the field. A critical opportunity for this coupling is the DNA assembly process. This project addresses the challenge of physically assembling DNA in an automated, optimized and efficient software and liquid handling workflow for a number of applications and assembly chemistries. This project will: (1) Develop a software library for DNA assembly protocols; (2) develop application software to create and manipulate DNA protocol and assembly graphs; (3) develop a common instruction set to abstract low level liquid handling; (4) experimentally create large, complex genetic regulatory networks (GRNs); and (5) expand synthetic biology outreach to K-12, undergraduate, graduate, and postdoctoral students to include automated DNA assembly.

Broader Impacts
Making open source, freely available DNA assembly software widely employed will change the entire "design-build-test" cycle proposed by synthetic biology. Industrially supported liquid handling robotic operations will unify the domain and make the creation of novel living systems cheaper, more reliable, and more accessible. The project's software will be the first of its kind publicly available. Educational outreach will be continued to introduce synthetic biology to underrepresented groups, undergraduates, and high school students thus training a future generation of engineering students. DNA assembly education will be made available to the International Genetically Engineered Machine (iGEM) software division. A "Registry of Synthetic Biology Software Tools" will be expanded to provide a community resource for bio-design automation software. Finally, the International Workshop on Bio-Design Automation (IWBDA) will expand its educational mission to provide additional DNA assembly tutorials, a PhD forum, and a formal mentorship program to match students with academic and industrial mentors.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Synthetic biology allows for the engineering of novel biological systems. One paradigm within the field is the assembly of small DNA pieces called "parts".  These parts are individually characterized regarding their function. It is the goal of the field to accurately predict the behavior of the composition of these pieces and therefore create new functionality from these primitive parts. This functionality includes new materials, therapeutics, sensors, and agriculture.

The major goals of this project were to create a complete automation platform which will translate high level DNA assembly plans for these parts into protocols which can be physically carried out by liquid handling automation. To do this we created the "Puppeteer" software platform. This is an open source project that provides this capability. It connects to a library of DNA parts, receives an assembly order, and uses those parts' physical location, properties, and availablity to command liquid handling robotics to assemble these parts into a composite DNA device. This not only increases the number of designs that can be made but more importantly increases the reproducibility and electronic tracking of the entire process.

In addition to liquid handling robots, these plans can also be given to microfluidic systems. To lower the barrier of entry to microfluidics and make it accessible to all researchers especially life science labs, we have utilized low-cost desktop computer numerically controlled (CNC) micromills to fabricate microfluidic devices out of a thermoplastic substrate (Polycarbonate). We provided a framework with a set of standard tests to characterize any CNC micromill in terms of spatial accuracy and surface quality. We then used this framework to characterize and compare the performance of three different low-cost (< $3500) CNC micromills.

To augment this microfluidic manufacturing capability, we have developed a graphical, web-based CAD tool (www.3duf.org) for designing continuous-flow microfluidic chips for use in synthetic biology laboratories. The basis of the design paradigm that drives this tool is that microfluidic chips, much like electronic computing systems, can be modularized, with each functional component having parameters that define a range of desirable behaviors, with the system as a whole comprising of multiple components connected to each other via channels.

In addition to the technical contributions of this work, educational activities helped to spread this methodology to undergraduate, graduate, and postdoctoral researchers. We helped to sponsor teams in 2014-2017 for the International Genetically Engineered Machine (iGEM) competition. Each of these teams won gold medals. We hosted more than ten undergrad students, two scientific staff members, and six graduate students developing projects and experiments in areas such as complex genetic circuit designs and DNA assembly.
